Article.ArticleTitle: Role of Ferryl Ion Intermediates in Fast Fenton Chemistry on Aqueous Microdroplets.

AbstractText: In the aqueous environment, Fe<sup>II</sup> ions enhance the oxidative potential of ozone and hydrogen peroxide by generating the reactive oxoiron species (ferryl ion, Fe<sup>IV</sup>O<sup>2+</sup>) and hydroxyl radical (·OH) via Fenton chemistry. Herein, we investigate factors that control the pathways of these reactive intermediates in the oxidation of dimethyl sulfoxide (Me<sub>2</sub>SO) in Fe<sup>II</sup> solutions reacting with O<sub>3</sub> in both bulk-phase water and on the surfaces of aqueous microdroplets. Electrospray ionization mass spectrometry is used to quantify the formation of dimethyl sulfone (Me<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>2</sub>, from Fe<sup>IV</sup>O<sup>2+</sup> + Me<sub>2</sub>SO) and methanesulfonate (MeSO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup>, from ·OH + Me<sub>2</sub>SO) over a wide range of Fe<sup>II</sup> and O<sub>3</sub> concentrations and pH. In addition, the role of environmentally relevant organic ligands on the reaction kinetics was also explored. The experimental results show that Fenton chemistry proceeds at a rate ∼10<sup>4</sup> times faster on microdroplets than that in bulk-phase water. Since the production of MeSO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> is initiated by ·OH radicals at diffusion-controlled rates, experimental ratios of Me<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>2</sub>/MeSO<sub>3</sub><sup>-</sup> > 10<sup>2</sup> suggest that Fe<sup>IV</sup>O<sup>2+</sup> is the dominant intermediate under all conditions. Me<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>2</sub> yields in the presence of ligands, L, vary as volcano-plot functions of E<sup>0</sup>(LFe<sup>IV</sup>O<sup>2+</sup>+ O<sub>2</sub>/LFe<sup>2+</sup> + O<sub>3</sub>) reduction potentials calculated by DFT with a maximum achieved in the case of L≡oxalate. Our findings underscore the key role of ferryl Fe<sup>IV</sup>O<sup>2+</sup> intermediates in Fenton chemistry taking place on aqueous microdroplets.
